Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: F: DKA: CSD: Iterative Crowdsourced Hypothesis Generation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Establishing causal relationships -- for example, that cigarette smoking causes lung cancer -- is one of the most challenging aspects of scientific research. Computers excel at calculation, but are unable to separate cause-and-effect from mere correlation. Humans, on the other hand, can make logical conclusions based on their experiences but, in the modern era of Big Data, there are far too many potential relationships for humans to manually examine. This research aims to build a crowdsourcing web platform to use the knowledge of interested non-experts (Hunch) and the algorithmic power of computers (Crunch) to discover and test causal relationships in large-scale data. Algorithms identify potential relationships and users are asked to validate them. Further, users are able to propose their own hypotheses that can subsequently be validated, creating an accelerating feedback loop of scientific discovery. The goal of systematically discovering causal relationships has the potential for broad societal impact, and virtually anyone with web access can participate directly in this scientific research.

To support this goal, the researchers are developing novel statistical methods that determine the data types of crowd-suggested observables on the fly. For example, are 'wages' and 'gender' real-valued or binary variables? Finally, the crowd is a relatively limited resource. To use it efficiently, machine learning algorithms would identify which substructures in the correlational network are most likely to be causal, and then focus the crowd's efforts towards them. These efficient, adaptive methods allow causal relationships to be combined into larger chains that explain growing numbers of causes and effects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project's major research goals were to develop and test methods for humans to use their intuitions and insights about the world in concert with computational big data analysis to address the central scientific question of distinguishing correlation from causation. We asked large groups of individuals using crowdsourcing if they felt a discovered correlation was indeed causal ("Do you think TOAST causes CRUMBS?"). When responding to these questions, crowdsource volunteers may potentially offer confounding factors or expansions of the causal pathway ("EATING toast causes crumbs"). Their responses lead to a growing network of questions and potential answers, from which we can extract new pathways of causes and effects. This growing network provides a novel dataset but studying it introduces an important algorithmic challenge: how to manage the valuable, limited time of the crowd efficiently. Computing is cheap nowadays, but human time is a limited resource that must be used well. We studied a variety of strategies to define and overcome this efficiency problem.

More generally, our work broadened to the idea of incorporating creative crowd contributions into crowdsourcing. Instead of asking people to perform rote tasks like answering multiple-choice questions, we studied ways crowd members could act creatively, for example, by posing new questions for other crowd members. Once again, this leads to a growing set of problems and all the efficiency challenges that growth entails. As machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI) continue to improve (and these techniques improved dramatically during the course of this project), fewer rote tasks will need human workers. Nevertheless, human creativity remains unsurpassed in most endeavors, underscoring the need to study ways to efficiently and reliably incorporate human creativity into large-scale scientific challenges.

The project supported 31 published or accepted journal and conference papers, with several works currently under review. We released code for an algorithm called NetFUSES (Network FUsion with SEmantic Similarity) that can study and combine networks with ambiguous elements (such as those produced by humans as they write free---and potentially ambiguous---natural language descriptions): https://github.com/baglab/netfuses Our paper (Berenberg & Bagrow, 2018) on an efficient algorithm for asking people to build a network of causes and effects received a Best Paper award at the 2018 ACM Conference on Computer-Supported Cooperative Work and Social Computing (CSCW), a leading venue for crowdsourcing and human-computer interaction research.


Educational outcomes and broader impacts

Two PhD students, three Master's students, and a research associate were supported under this project. Two Master's students and the research associate were female. One PhD student is now a tenure-track assistant professor. One Master's student, who began on the project as an undergraduate, later worked as a research analyst in a systems biology lab and is currently a full-time PhD student. The other Master's students both now work in industry as data analysts, one in the field of education and the other in renewable energy. The project provided opportunities and support for the PI and students to present their work at conferences. The research outcomes described above significantly informed new modules in the PI's data science courses for both undergraduate and graduate students.
